title: System and Communications Protection
description: Protecting system boundaries, communications, and data in transit

questions.question: Do you monitor and protect your network boundaries?
questions.context: Your firewall and network security - protecting the perimeter.
questions.examples: Firewall configured and enabled, network monitoring
questions.followUp: What firewall do you use? Is it actively monitored?

questions.question: Do you use architectural designs to protect your systems?
questions.context: Network segmentation, DMZs, and layered defenses protect CUI systems.
questions.examples: Network segmentation, VLANs, DMZ, defense in depth, zero trust
questions.followUp: How is your network segmented? Are CUI systems isolated? Any architectural diagrams?
questions.discussion: Security architecture uses segmentation, layering, and defense-in-depth to protect critical assets and limit breach impact.

questions.question: Do you separate user functionality from system management?
questions.context: Admin functions should be separated from user activities for security.
questions.examples: Separate admin network, jump boxes, privileged access workstations
questions.followUp: How do admins access systems? Any separation from user network? Dedicated admin workstations?
questions.discussion: Separating user and management functionality reduces risk by isolating administrative access from general user activities.

questions.question: Do you prevent unauthorized information transfer between systems?
questions.context: Data shouldn't leak between different security levels or to unauthorized systems.
questions.examples: Data loss prevention, network controls, USB blocking, email filtering
questions.followUp: How do you prevent data leakage? Any DLP tools? Controls on data movement?
questions.discussion: Preventing unauthorized information transfer stops data leakage and maintains separation between different security domains.

questions.question: Do you use publicly available security guidance?
questions.context: Using known bad IP lists, security updates from vendors.
questions.examples: Windows Defender updates, firewall deny lists, threat feeds
questions.followUp: How do security tools get updated? Automatically?

questions.question: Do you deny network traffic by default and allow by exception?
questions.context: Firewalls should block everything except specifically allowed traffic.
questions.examples: Default deny rules, whitelist approach, explicit allow rules
questions.followUp: What's your firewall default policy? How are exceptions approved? Any review of rules?
questions.discussion: Deny-by-default ensures only explicitly authorized communications occur, reducing attack surface and preventing unauthorized access.

questions.question: Do you prevent split tunneling for remote devices?
questions.context: Remote devices shouldn't connect to your network and the internet simultaneously.
questions.examples: VPN forced tunneling, no split tunneling, all traffic through VPN
questions.followUp: Can remote users access internet directly while on VPN? Any exceptions?
questions.discussion: Preventing split tunneling ensures remote device traffic goes through organizational security controls, preventing bypass attacks.

questions.question: Do you implement cryptographic mechanisms for CUI transmission?
questions.context: CUI must be encrypted when transmitted over networks.
questions.examples: TLS/SSL, VPN encryption, encrypted email, SFTP instead of FTP
questions.followUp: How is CUI encrypted in transit? What protocols are used? Any unencrypted transmission?
questions.discussion: Cryptographic protection prevents unauthorized disclosure of CUI during transmission over networks.

questions.question: Do you terminate network connections at end of sessions?
questions.context: Connections should end when no longer needed to free resources and reduce risk.
questions.examples: Session timeouts, automatic disconnection, idle timeouts
questions.followUp: When do sessions terminate? What are timeout settings? Any persistent connections?
questions.discussion: Terminating idle connections reduces the risk of unauthorized access through hijacked or forgotten sessions.

questions.question: Do you establish and manage cryptographic keys?
questions.context: Encryption keys need proper generation, distribution, storage, and destruction.
questions.examples: Key management system, certificate authority, key escrow, key rotation
questions.followUp: How are encryption keys managed? Who has access? How often are they changed?
questions.discussion: Proper key management ensures cryptographic protections remain effective and keys aren't compromised.

questions.question: Do you use FIPS-validated cryptography for CUI?
questions.context: CUI requires FIPS 140-2 validated encryption modules.
questions.examples: FIPS 140-2 modules, AES encryption, approved algorithms
questions.followUp: What encryption do you use? Is it FIPS validated? Any non-FIPS encryption?
questions.discussion: FIPS-validated cryptography ensures encryption meets federal standards for protecting CUI.

questions.question: Do you prohibit remote activation of collaborative computing devices?
questions.context: Cameras and microphones shouldn't be activated remotely without user knowledge.
questions.examples: Disabled remote activation, physical disconnects, indicator lights
questions.followUp: Can cameras/mics be activated remotely? Any physical controls? User notifications?
questions.discussion: Prohibiting remote activation prevents unauthorized surveillance and eavesdropping through collaborative computing devices.

questions.question: Do you control use of mobile code?
questions.context: JavaScript, ActiveX, and other mobile code can be security risks.
questions.examples: Mobile code policies, browser restrictions, sandboxing, code signing
questions.followUp: What mobile code is allowed? Any restrictions? How are they enforced?
questions.discussion: Mobile code restrictions prevent malicious code execution through web browsers and applications.

questions.question: Do you control use of Voice over IP (VoIP)?
questions.context: VoIP can bypass security controls and needs specific protections.
questions.examples: VoIP policy, encrypted VoIP, separate VLANs, monitoring
questions.followUp: Do you use VoIP? How is it secured? Any monitoring? Separate from data network?
questions.discussion: VoIP technologies require specific security controls to prevent eavesdropping and service disruption.

questions.question: Do you protect authenticity of communications sessions?
questions.context: Sessions should be protected from hijacking and man-in-the-middle attacks.
questions.examples: Session encryption, mutual authentication, integrity checking
questions.followUp: How are sessions protected? Any mutual authentication? Integrity checks?
questions.discussion: Session authenticity protection prevents session hijacking and ensures communications are with legitimate parties.

questions.question: Do you protect CUI at rest?
questions.context: Stored CUI needs encryption or equivalent protection.
questions.examples: Full disk encryption, database encryption, file encryption
questions.followUp: How is stored CUI protected? What encryption is used? Any unencrypted storage?
questions.discussion: Protecting CUI at rest prevents unauthorized disclosure if storage media is lost, stolen, or accessed without authorization.
